prop.name: keywords
prop.value: critical infrastructure, cybersecurity, information security, information system, OSCAL, Open Security Controls Assessment Language, security functions, security requirements, system, system security

party.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology

address.addr-line: National Institute of Standards and Technology

part.name: instruction
part.p: Establish and monitor the organization's cybersecurity risk management strategy, expectations, and policy

part.name: statement
part.p: The circumstances - mission, stakeholder expectations, and legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements - surrounding the organization's cybersecurity risk management decisions are understood (formerly ID.BE)

part.name: statement
part.p: The organizational mission is understood and informs cybersecurity risk management (formerly ID.BE-02, ID.BE-03)

part.name: example
part.p: Share the organization's mission (e.g., through vision and mission statements, marketing, and service strategies) to provide a basis for identifying risks that may impede that mission

part.name: statement
part.p: Internal and external stakeholders are determined, and their needs and expectations regarding cybersecurity risk management are understood

part.name: example
part.p: Identify relevant internal stakeholders and their cybersecurity-related expectations (e.g., performance and risk expectations of officers, directors, and advisors; cultural expectations of employees)

part.name: statement
part.p: Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding cybersecurity - including privacy and civil liberties obligations - are understood and managed (formerly ID.GV-03)

part.name: example
part.p: Determine a process to track and manage legal and regulatory requirements regarding protection of individuals' information (e.g., Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, California Consumer Privacy Act, General Data Protection Regulation)

part.name: statement
part.p: Critical objectives, capabilities, and services that stakeholders depend on or expect from the organization are determined and communicated (formerly ID.BE-04, ID.BE-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Establish criteria for determining the criticality of capabilities and services as viewed by internal and external stakeholders

part.name: statement
part.p: Outcomes, capabilities, and services that the organization depends on are determined and communicated (formerly ID.BE-01, ID.BE-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Create an inventory of the organization's dependencies on external resources (e.g., facilities, cloud-based hosting providers) and their relationships to organizational assets and business functions

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization's priorities, constraints, risk tolerance and appetite statements, and assumptions are established, communicated, and used to support operational risk decisions (formerly ID.RM)

part.name: statement
part.p: Risk management objectives are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders (formerly ID.RM-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Update near-term and long-term cybersecurity risk management objectives as part of annual strategic planning and when major changes occur

part.name: statement
part.p: Risk appetite and risk tolerance statements are determined, communicated, and maintained (formerly ID.RM-02, ID.RM-03)

part.name: example
part.p: Determine and communicate risk appetite statements that convey expectations about the appropriate level of risk for the organization

part.name: statement
part.p: Enterprise risk management processes include cybersecurity risk management activities and outcomes (formerly ID.GV-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Aggregate and manage cybersecurity risks alongside other enterprise risks (e.g., compliance, financial, regulatory)

part.name: statement
part.p: Strategic direction that describes appropriate risk response options is established and communicated

part.name: example
part.p: Specify criteria for accepting and avoiding cybersecurity risk for various classifications of data

part.name: statement
part.p: Lines of communication across the organization are established for cybersecurity risks, including risks from suppliers and other third parties

part.name: example
part.p: Determine how to update senior executives, directors, and management on the organization's cybersecurity posture at agreed-upon intervals

part.name: statement
part.p: A standardized method for calculating, documenting, categorizing, and prioritizing cybersecurity risks is established and communicated

part.name: example
part.p: Establish criteria for using a quantitative approach to cybersecurity risk analysis, and specify probability and exposure formulas

part.name: statement
part.p: Strategic opportunities (i.e., positive risks) are identified and included in organizational cybersecurity risk discussions

part.name: example
part.p: Define and communicate guidance and methods for identifying opportunities and including them in risk discussions (e.g., strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats [SWOT] analysis)

part.name: statement
part.p: Cyber supply chain risk management processes are identified, established, managed, monitored, and improved by organizational stakeholders (formerly ID.SC)

part.name: statement
part.p: A cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, strategy, objectives, policies, and processes are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders (formerly ID.SC-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Establish a strategy that expresses the objectives of the cybersecurity supply chain risk management program

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and partners are established, communicated, and coordinated internally and externally (formerly ID.AM-06)

part.name: example
part.p: Identify one or more specific roles or positions that will be responsible and accountable for planning, resourcing, and executing cybersecurity supply chain risk management activities

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management is integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management, risk assessment, and improvement processes (formerly ID.SC-02)

part.name: example
part.p: Identify areas of alignment and overlap with cybersecurity and enterprise risk management

part.name: statement
part.p: Suppliers are known and prioritized by criticality

part.name: example
part.p: Develop criteria for supplier criticality based on, for example, the sensitivity of data processed or possessed by suppliers, the degree of access to the organization's systems, and the importance of the products or services to the organization's mission

part.name: statement
part.p: Requirements to address cybersecurity risks in supply chains are established, prioritized, and integrated into contracts and other types of agreements with suppliers and other relevant third parties (formerly ID.SC-03)

part.name: example
part.p: Establish security requirements for suppliers, products, and services commensurate with their criticality level and potential impact if compromised

part.name: statement
part.p: Planning and due diligence are performed to reduce risks before entering into formal supplier or other third-party relationships

part.name: example
part.p: Perform thorough due diligence on prospective suppliers that is consistent with procurement planning and commensurate with the level of risk, criticality, and complexity of each supplier relationship

part.name: statement
part.p: The risks posed by a supplier, their products and services, and other third parties are identified, recorded, prioritized, assessed, responded to, and monitored over the course of the relationship (formerly ID.SC-02, ID.SC-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Adjust assessment formats and frequencies based on the third party's reputation and the criticality of the products or services they provide

part.name: statement
part.p: Relevant suppliers and other third parties are included in incident planning, response, and recovery activities (formerly ID.SC-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Define and use rules and protocols for reporting incident response and recovery activities and the status between the organization and its suppliers

part.name: statement
part.p: Supply chain security practices are integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management programs, and their performance is monitored throughout the technology product and service life cycle

part.name: example
part.p: Policies and procedures require provenance records for all acquired technology products and services

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management plans include provisions for activities that occur after the conclusion of a partnership or service agreement

part.name: example
part.p: Establish processes for terminating critical relationships under both normal and adverse circumstances

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity roles, responsibilities, and authorities to foster accountability, performance assessment, and continuous improvement are established and communicated (formerly ID.GV-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Organizational leadership is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk and fosters a culture that is risk-aware, ethical, and continually improving

part.name: example
part.p: Leaders (e.g., directors) agree on their roles and responsibilities in developing, implementing, and assessing the organization's cybersecurity strategy

part.name: statement
part.p: Roles, responsibilities, and authorities related to cybersecurity risk management are established, communicated, understood, and enforced (formerly ID.AM-06, ID.GV-02, DE.DP-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Document risk management roles and responsibilities in policy

part.name: statement
part.p: Adequate resources are allocated commensurate with cybersecurity risk strategy, roles and responsibilities, and policies

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct periodic management reviews to ensure that those given cybersecurity risk management responsibilities have the necessary authority

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices (formerly PR.IP-11)

part.name: example
part.p: Integrate cybersecurity risk management considerations into human resources processes (e.g., personnel screening, onboarding, change notification, offboarding)

part.name: statement
part.p: Organizational cybersecurity policies, processes, and procedures are established, communicated, and enforced (formerly ID.GV-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Policies, processes, and procedures for managing cybersecurity risks are established based on organizational context, cybersecurity strategy, and priorities and are communicated and enforced (formerly ID.GV-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Create, disseminate, and maintain a risk management policy with statements of management intent, expectations, and direction

part.name: statement
part.p: Policies, processes, and procedures for managing cybersecurity risks are reviewed, updated, communicated, and enforced to reflect changes in requirements, threats, technology, and organizational mission (formerly ID.GV-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Update policies based on periodic reviews of cybersecurity risk management results to ensure that policies and supporting processes adequately maintain risk at an acceptable level

part.name: statement
part.p: Results of organization-wide cybersecurity risk management activities and performance are used to inform, improve, and adjust the risk management strategy

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity risk management strategy outcomes are reviewed to inform and adjust strategy and direction

part.name: example
part.p: Measure how well the risk management strategy and risk results have helped leaders make decisions and achieve organizational objectives

part.name: statement
part.p: The cybersecurity risk management strategy is reviewed and adjusted to ensure coverage of organizational requirements and risks

part.name: example
part.p: Review audit findings to confirm whether the existing cybersecurity strategy has ensured compliance with internal and external requirements

part.name: statement
part.p: Organizational cybersecurity risk management performance is measured and reviewed to confirm and adjust strategic direction

part.name: example
part.p: Review key performance indicators (KPIs) to ensure that organization-wide policies and procedures achieve objectives

part.name: instruction
part.p: Help determine the current cybersecurity risk to the organization

part.name: statement
part.p: Assets (e.g., data, hardware software, systems, facilities, services, people) that enable the organization to achieve business purposes are identified and managed consistent with their relative importance to organizational objectives and the organization's risk strategy

part.name: statement
part.p: Inventories of hardware managed by the organization are maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain inventories for all types of hardware, including IT, IoT, OT, and mobile devices

part.name: statement
part.p: Inventories of software, services, and systems managed by the organization are maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain inventories for all types of software and services, including commercial-off-the-shelf, open-source, custom applications, API services, and cloud-based applications and services

part.name: statement
part.p: Representations of the organization's authorized network communication and internal and external network data flows are maintained (formerly ID.AM-03, DE.AE-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain baselines of communication and data flows within the organization's wired and wireless networks

part.name: statement
part.p: Inventories of services provided by suppliers are maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Inventory all external services used by the organization, including third-party infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), platform-as-a-service (PaaS), and software-as-a-service (SaaS) offerings; APIs; and other externally hosted application services

part.name: statement
part.p: Assets are prioritized based on classification, criticality, resources, and impact on the mission

part.name: example
part.p: Define criteria for prioritizing each class of assets

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.RR-02, GV.SC-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Inventories of data and corresponding metadata for designated data types are maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain a list of the designated data types of interest (e.g., personally identifiable information, protected health information, financial account numbers, organization intellectual property)

part.name: statement
part.p: Systems, hardware, software, and services are managed throughout their life cycle (formerly PR.DS-03, PR.IP-02, PR.MA-01, PR.MA-02)

part.name: example
part.p: Integrate cybersecurity considerations throughout the life cycles of systems, hardware, software, and services

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.OC)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.OC-05)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.OC-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.OC-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.OC-04, GV.OC-05)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.OC-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.PO)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.RR-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.OC-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.RM-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization understands the cybersecurity risk to the organization, assets, and individuals.

part.name: statement
part.p: Vulnerabilities in assets are identified, validated, and recorded (formerly ID.RA-01, PR.IP-12, DE.CM-08)

part.name: example
part.p: Use vulnerability management technologies to identify unpatched and misconfigured software

part.name: statement
part.p: Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums and sources

part.name: example
part.p: Configure cybersecurity tools and technologies with detection or response capabilities to securely ingest cyber threat intelligence feeds

part.name: statement
part.p: Internal and external threats to the organization are identified and recorded

part.name: example
part.p: Use cyber threat intelligence to maintain awareness of the types of threat actors likely to target the organization and the TTPs they are likely to use

part.name: statement
part.p: Potential impacts and likelihoods of threats exploiting vulnerabilities are identified and recorded

part.name: example
part.p: Business leaders and cybersecurity risk management practitioners work together to estimate the likelihood and impact of risk scenarios and record them in risk registers

part.name: statement
part.p: Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts are used to determine risk and inform risk prioritization

part.name: example
part.p: Develop threat models to better understand risks to the data and identify appropriate risk responses

part.name: statement
part.p: Risk responses are chosen from the available options, prioritized, planned, tracked, and communicated (formerly ID.RA-06, RS.MI-03)

part.name: example
part.p: Apply the vulnerability management plan's criteria for deciding whether to accept, transfer, mitigate, or avoid risk

part.name: statement
part.p: Changes and exceptions are managed, assessed for risk impact, recorded, and tracked (formerly part of PR.IP-03)

part.name: example
part.p: Implement and follow procedures for the formal documentation, review, testing, and approval of proposed changes and requested exceptions

part.name: statement
part.p: Processes for receiving, analyzing, and responding to vulnerability disclosures are established (formerly RS.AN-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct vulnerability information sharing between the organization and its suppliers following the rules and protocols defined in contracts

part.name: statement
part.p: The authenticity and integrity of hardware and software are assessed prior to acquisition and use (formerly PR.DS-08)

part.name: example
part.p: Assess the authenticity and cybersecurity of critical technology products and services prior to acquisition and use

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.RM)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.RM-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.RM-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.RM-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.SC)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.SC-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.SC-03, GV.SC-07)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.SC-05)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.SC-07)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.SC-08, ID.IM-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Improvements to organizational cybersecurity risk management processes, procedures and activities are identified across all Framework Functions

part.name: statement
part.p: Continuous evaluation is applied to identify improvements

part.name: example
part.p: Perform self-assessments of critical services that take current threats and TTPs into consideration

part.name: statement
part.p: Security tests and exercises, including those done in coordination with suppliers and relevant third parties, are conducted to identify improvements (formerly ID.SC-05, PR.IP-10, DE.DP-03)

part.name: example
part.p: Identify improvements for future incident response activities based on findings from incident response assessments (e.g., tabletop exercises and simulations, tests, internal reviews, independent audits)

part.name: statement
part.p: Lessons learned during execution of operational processes, procedures, and activities are used to identify improvements (formerly PR.IP-07, PR.IP-08, DE.DP-05, RS.IM-01, RS.IM-02, RC.IM-01, RC.IM-02)

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct collaborative lessons learned sessions with suppliers

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity plans that affect operations are communicated, maintained, and improved (formerly PR.IP-09)

part.name: example
part.p: Establish contingency plans (e.g., incident response, business continuity, disaster recovery) for responding to and recovering from adverse events that can interfere with operations, expose confidential information, or otherwise endanger the organization's mission and viability

part.name: instruction
part.p: Use safeguards to prevent or reduce cybersecurity risk

control.title: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control

part.name: statement
part.p: Access to physical and logical assets is limited to authorized users, services, and hardware, and is managed commensurate with the assessed risk of unauthorized access (formerly PR.AC)

part.name: statement
part.p: Identities and credentials for authorized users, services, and hardware are managed by the organization (formerly PR.AC-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Initiate requests for new access or additional access for employees, contractors, and others, and track, review, and fulfill the requests, with permission from system or data owners when needed

part.name: statement
part.p: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials based on the context of interactions (formerly PR.AC-06)

part.name: example
part.p: Verify a person's claimed identity at enrollment time using government-issued identity credentials (e.g., passport, visa, driver's license)

part.name: statement
part.p: Users, services, and hardware are authenticated (formerly PR.AC-03, PR.AC-07)

part.name: example
part.p: Require multifactor authentication

part.name: statement
part.p: Identity assertions are protected, conveyed, and verified

part.name: example
part.p: Protect identity assertions that are used to convey authentication and user information through single sign-on systems

part.name: statement
part.p: Access permissions, entitlements, and authorizations are defined in a policy, managed, enforced, and reviewed, and incorporate the principles of least privilege and separation of duties (formerly PR.AC-01, PR.AC-03, PR.AC-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Review logical and physical access privileges periodically and whenever someone changes roles or leaves the organization, and promptly rescind privileges that are no longer needed

part.name: statement
part.p: Physical access to assets is managed, monitored, and enforced commensurate with risk (formerly PR.AC-02, PR.PT-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Use security guards, security cameras, locked entrances, alarm systems, and other physical controls to monitor facilities and restrict access

control.title: Identity Management, Authentication and Access Control

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AA)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AA-01, PR.AA-05)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AA-06)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AA-03, PR.AA-05, PR.IR-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AA-05)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.IR-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AA-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AA-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization's personnel are provided cybersecurity awareness and training so they can perform their cybersecurity-related tasks

part.name: statement
part.p: Users are provided awareness and training so they possess the knowledge and skills to perform general tasks with security risks in mind (formerly PR.AT-01, PR.AT-03, RS.CO-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Provide basic cybersecurity awareness and training to employees, contractors, partners, suppliers, and all other users of the organization's non-public resources

part.name: statement
part.p: Individuals in specialized roles are provided awareness and training so they possess the knowledge and skills to perform relevant tasks with security risks in mind (formerly PR.AT-02, PR.AT-03, PR.AT-04, PR.AT-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Identify the specialized roles within the organization that require additional cybersecurity training, such as physical and cybersecurity personnel, finance personnel, senior leadership, and anyone with access to business-critical data

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AT-01, PR.AT-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AT-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AT-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Data is managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information

part.name: statement
part.p: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-at-rest are protected (formerly PR.DS-01, PR-DS.05, PR.DS-06, PR.PT-02)

part.name: example
part.p: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of stored data in files, databases, virtual machine disk images, container images, and other resources

part.name: statement
part.p: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-transit are protected (formerly PR.DS-02, PR.DS-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of network communications

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.AM-08)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.IR-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.DS-01, PR-DS-02, PR.DS-10)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.DS-01, DE.CM-09)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.IR-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.RA-09, DE.CM-09)

part.name: statement
part.p: Data is managed throughout its life cycle, including destruction (formerly PR.IP-06)

part.name: example
part.p: Securely destroy stored data based on the organization's data retention policy using the prescribed destruction method

part.name: statement
part.p: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-use are protected (formerly PR.DS-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Remove data that must remain confidential (e.g., from processors and memory) as soon as it is no longer needed

part.name: statement
part.p: Backups of data are created, protected, maintained, and tested (formerly PR.IP-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Continuously back up critical data in near-real-time, and back up other data frequently at agreed-upon schedules

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to other Categories and Functions)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.PS-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.AM-08)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.PS-01, ID.RA-07)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.DS-11)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.IR-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.DS-09)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.RR-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.RA-01, PR.PS-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.AM-08)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.AM-08, PR.PS-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.AM-08, PR.PS-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to other Protect Categories)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.PS-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.DS-01, PR.PS-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.PS-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AA-07, PR.IR-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.IR-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: The hardware, software (e.g., firmware, operating systems, applications), and services of physical and virtual platforms are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect their confidentiality, integrity, and availability

part.name: statement
part.p: Configuration management practices are applied (formerly PR.IP-01, PR.IP-03, PR.PT-02, PR.PT-03)

part.name: example
part.p: Establish, test, deploy, and maintain hardened baselines that enforce the organization's cybersecurity policies and provide only essential capabilities (i.e., principle of least functionality)

part.name: statement
part.p: Software is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk (formerly PR.IP-12, PR.MA-02)

part.name: example
part.p: Perform routine and emergency patching within the timeframes specified in the vulnerability management plan

part.name: statement
part.p: Hardware is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk (formerly PR.MA-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Replace hardware when it lacks needed security capabilities or when it cannot support software with needed security capabilities

part.name: statement
part.p: Log records are generated and made available for continuous monitoring (formerly PR.PT-01)

part.name: example
part.p: Configure all operating systems, applications, and services (including cloud-based services) to generate log records

part.name: statement
part.p: Installation and execution of unauthorized software are prevented

part.name: example
part.p: When risk warrants it, restrict software execution to permitted products only or deny the execution of prohibited and unauthorized software

part.name: statement
part.p: Secure software development practices are integrated and their performance is monitored throughout the software development life cycle

part.name: example
part.p: Protect all components of organization-developed software from tampering and unauthorized access

part.name: statement
part.p: Security architectures are managed with the organization's risk strategy to protect asset confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and organizational resilience

part.name: statement
part.p: Networks and environments are protected from unauthorized logical access and usage (formerly PR.AC-03, PR.AC-05, PR.DS-07, PR.PT-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Logically segment organization networks and cloud-based platforms according to trust boundaries and platform types (e.g., IT, IoT, OT, mobile, guests), and permit required communications only between segments

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization's technology assets are protected from environmental threats (formerly PR.IP-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Protect organizational equipment from known environmental threats, such as flooding, fire, wind, and excessive heat and humidity

part.name: statement
part.p: Mechanisms are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations (formerly PR.PT-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Avoid single points of failure in systems and infrastructure

part.name: statement
part.p: Adequate resource capacity to ensure availability is maintained (formerly PR.DS-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor usage of storage, power, compute, network bandwidth, and other resources

part.name: instruction
part.p: Find and analyze possible cybersecurity attacks and compromises

part.name: statement
part.p: Assets are monitored to find anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events

part.name: statement
part.p: Networks and network services are monitored to find potentially adverse events (formerly DE.CM-01, DE.CM-04, DE.CM-05, DE.CM-07)

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor DNS, BGP, and other network services for adverse events

part.name: statement
part.p: The physical environment is monitored to find potentially adverse events

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor logs from physical access control systems (e.g., badge readers) to find unusual access patterns (e.g., deviations from the norm) and failed access attempts

part.name: statement
part.p: Personnel activity and technology usage are monitored to find potentially adverse events (formerly DE.CM-03, DE.CM-07)

part.name: example
part.p: Use behavior analytics software to detect anomalous user activity to mitigate insider threats

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to DE.CM-01, DE.CM-09)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to DE.CM-01, DE.CM-09)

part.name: statement
part.p: External service provider activities and services are monitored to find potentially adverse events (formerly DE.CM-06, DE.CM-07)

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor remote administration and maintenance activities that external providers perform on organizational systems

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to DE.CM-01, DE.CM-03, DE.CM-06, DE.CM-09)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.RA-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Computing hardware and software, runtime environments, and their data are monitored to find potentially adverse events (formerly PR.DS-06, PR.DS-08, DE.CM-04, DE.CM-05, DE.CM-07)

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor email, web, file sharing, collaboration services, and other common attack vectors to detect malware, phishing, data leaks and exfiltration, and other adverse events

part.name: statement
part.p: Anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events are analyzed to characterize the events and detect cybersecurity incidents (formerly DE.AE, DE.DP-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.AM-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: Potentially adverse events are analyzed to better understand associated activities

part.name: example
part.p: Use security information and event management (SIEM) or other tools to continuously monitor log events for known malicious and suspicious activity

part.name: statement
part.p: Information is correlated from multiple sources

part.name: example
part.p: Constantly transfer log data generated by other sources to a relatively small number of log servers

part.name: statement
part.p: The estimated impact and scope of adverse events are determined

part.name: example
part.p: Use SIEMs or other tools to estimate impact and scope, and review and refine the estimates

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to DE.AE-08)

part.name: statement
part.p: Information on adverse events is provided to authorized staff and tools (formerly DE.DP-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Use cybersecurity software to generate alerts and provide them to the security operations center (SOC), incident responders, and incident response tools

part.name: statement
part.p: Cyber threat intelligence and other contextual information are integrated into the analysis

part.name: example
part.p: Securely provide cyber threat intelligence feeds to detection technologies, processes, and personnel

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are declared when adverse events meet the defined incident criteria (formerly DE.AE-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Apply incident criteria to known and assumed characteristics of activity in order to determine whether an incident should be declared

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to other Categories and Functions)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to GV.RR-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to DE.AE)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to DE.AE-06)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-03)

part.name: instruction
part.p: Take action regarding a detected cybersecurity incident

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to RS.MA)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to RS.MA-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Responses to detected cybersecurity incidents are managed (formerly RS.RP)

part.name: statement
part.p: The incident response plan is executed once an incident is declared in coordination with relevant third parties (formerly RS.RP-01, RS.CO-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Detection technologies automatically report confirmed incidents

part.name: statement
part.p: Incident reports are triaged and validated (formerly RS.AN-01, RS.AN-02)

part.name: example
part.p: Preliminarily review incident reports to confirm that they are cybersecurity-related and necessitate incident response activities

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are categorized and prioritized (formerly RS.AN-04, RS.AN-02)

part.name: example
part.p: Further review and categorize incidents based on the type of incident (e.g., data breach, ransomware, DDoS, account compromise)

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are escalated or elevated as needed (formerly RS.AN-02, RS.CO-04)

part.name: example
part.p: Track and validate the status of all ongoing incidents

part.name: statement
part.p: The criteria for initiating incident recovery are applied

part.name: example
part.p: Apply incident recovery criteria to known and assumed characteristics of the incident to determine whether incident recovery processes should be initiated

part.name: statement
part.p: Investigation is conducted to ensure effective response and support forensics and recovery activities

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to RS.MA-02)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to RS.MA-02, RS.MA-03, RS.MA-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: Analysis is performed to determine what has taken place during an incident and the root cause of the incident

part.name: example
part.p: Determine the sequence of events that occurred during the incident and which assets and resources were involved in each event

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to RS.MA-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.RA-08)

part.name: statement
part.p: Actions performed during an investigation are recorded and the records' integrity and provenance are preserved (formerly part of RS.AN-03)

part.name: example
part.p: Require each incident responder and others (e.g., system administrators, cybersecurity engineers) who perform incident response tasks to record their actions and make the record immutable

part.name: statement
part.p: Incident data and metadata are collected, and their integrity and provenance are preserved

part.name: example
part.p: Collect, preserve, and safeguard the integrity of all pertinent incident data and metadata (e.g., data source, date/time of collection) based on evidence preservation and chain-of-custody procedures

part.name: statement
part.p: The incident's magnitude is estimated and validated

part.name: example
part.p: Review other potential targets of the incident to search for indicators of compromise and evidence of persistence

part.name: statement
part.p: Response activities are coordinated with internal and external stakeholders as required by laws, regulations, or policies

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to PR.AT-01)

part.name: statement
part.p: Internal and external stakeholders are notified of incidents

part.name: example
part.p: Follow the organization's breach notification procedures after discovering a data breach incident, including notifying affected customers

part.name: statement
part.p: Information is shared with designated internal and external stakeholders (formerly RS.CO-03, RS.CO-05)

part.name: example
part.p: Securely share information consistent with response plans and information sharing agreements

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to RS.MA-01, RS.MA-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to RS.CO-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: Activities are performed to prevent expansion of an event and mitigate its effects

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are contained

part.name: example
part.p: Cybersecurity technologies (e.g., antivirus software) and cybersecurity features of other technologies (e.g., operating systems, network infrastructure devices) automatically perform containment actions

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are eradicated

part.name: example
part.p: Cybersecurity technologies and cybersecurity features of other technologies (e.g., operating systems, network infrastructure devices) automatically perform eradication actions

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.RA-06)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-03)

part.name: instruction
part.p: Restore assets and operations that were impacted by a cybersecurity incident

part.name: statement
part.p: Restoration activities are performed to ensure operational availability of systems and services affected by cybersecurity incidents

part.name: statement
part.p: The recovery portion of the incident response plan is executed once initiated from the incident response process

part.name: example
part.p: Begin recovery procedures during or after incident response processes

part.name: statement
part.p: Recovery actions are determined, scoped, prioritized, and performed

part.name: example
part.p: Select recovery actions based on the criteria defined in the incident response plan and available resources

part.name: statement
part.p: The integrity of backups and other restoration assets is verified before using them for restoration

part.name: example
part.p: Check restoration assets for indicators of compromise, file corruption, and other integrity issues before use

part.name: statement
part.p: Critical mission functions and cybersecurity risk management are considered to establish post-incident operational norms

part.name: example
part.p: Use business impact and system categorization records (including service delivery objectives) to validate that essential services are restored in the appropriate order

part.name: statement
part.p: The integrity of restored assets is verified, systems and services are restored, and normal operating status is confirmed

part.name: example
part.p: Check restored assets for indicators of compromise and remediation of root causes of the incident before production use

part.name: statement
part.p: The criteria for determining the end of incident recovery are applied, and incident-related documentation is completed

part.name: example
part.p: Prepare an after-action report that documents the incident itself, the response and recovery actions taken, and lessons learned

part.name: statement
part.p: Restoration activities are coordinated with internal and external parties

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to RC.CO-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to RC.CO-04)

part.name: statement
part.p: Recovery activities and progress in restoring operational capabilities are communicated to designated internal and external stakeholders

part.name: example
part.p: Securely share recovery information, including restoration progress, consistent with response plans and information sharing agreements

part.name: statement
part.p: Public updates on incident recovery are properly shared using approved methods and messaging (formerly RC.CO-01, RC.CO-02)

part.name: example
part.p: Follow the organization's breach notification procedures for recovering from a data breach incident

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-03)

part.name: statement
part.p: Dropped (moved to ID.IM-03)
